## Requirements (I _think_)

- Be high-quality research in the traditional sense
  - novel, useful and impactful
- Avoid competing with UCL's existing research
- Align with dRTP values
  - open-source, recognition for technical contributions, sustainability, accessibility, ...
- Align with UCL & funding agencies' priorities
- Be fun

## Possible implementation approaches

- Research about the dRTP profession
- Research in our existing backgrounds

# Background

## ARC people know a lot

Three pieces of open-source software that ARC knows about

* NekMesh is good at making meshes
* FEniCS is good at solving partial differential equations
* BrainGlobe is good at aligning images to a common space

## FEniCS solves equations on meshes

![](img/fenics-elasticity.png){ height=500px }

::: aside
Meshes should be "mathematically nice" so we can solve equations on them.
Meshing complex geometries like biological organs is hard and doesn't scale well.
:::


## BrainGlobe is good at aligning images to a common space

![](img/brain-atlas-mapping.png){ width=400px }

## Annotate once, map annotations to many

![](img/brain-atlas-mapping-with-annotations.png){ width=400px }

## What if we could mesh only once?
Using the same image alignment approach

![](img/brain-atlas-mapping-with-mesh.png){ width=700px }

::: aside
This means building the mapping into the equations.
:::

## A remixing example

* Take the idea mapping to atlas space from BrainGlobe
* Augment the idea with a atlas space volumetric mesh
* Solve PDEs for many samples on the atlas space mesh with FEniCS - scales well!
* (PDEs are not so interesting for brains, but they are for other organs, like bones!)
